question: Relative to the horizon, how does a constellation’s position appear to change during the night?

content.source_1: Earth rotates west-to-east once per sidereal day (~23h56m), making the celestial sphere (including constellations) appear to drift from east to west across the sky.
content.source_2: Over the course of hours, stars and constellations rise above the eastern horizon, cross the sky, and set in the west; their internal star pattern (shape) remains essentially unchanged while they move.
content.source_3: Because the stars in a constellation are extremely distant, their relative positions do not change perceptibly over a single night; the pattern retains the same shape.
content.source_4: As the night progresses, constellations that were below the horizon earlier in the evening become visible by appearing above the eastern horizon.
content.source_5: Any celestial object that rises does so on the eastern side of the horizon; “rising” denotes emergence in the east.
content.source_6: The apparent daily motion of the stars is a rotation of the sky about the celestial pole; stars trace diurnal circles centered on that point.

answer: Its position appears to shift relative to the horizon.
